review_blob: Dryer than its brother the Aurora Australis and very fragrant thanks to the cognac barrel ageing. A very enjoyable beer and perfect with some blue cheese and toasted sour dough. If you can get it do so.
beer_name: Ngne  / Bridge Road Aurora Borealis II

review_blob: Tasted side by side with its brother the Aurora Borealis 2 and some nice blue cheese. Deep reddish brown with tan head that lasted well. Dried plums, spice and cinnamon. Warming and luxurious mouth feel. Very enjoyable and contrasting to the Borealis which is aged in cognac casks.

Couldnt get this at the Bridge Road Brewery but Provenance Restaurant had one. At $20 it was well worth it and probably one of the most unique beers in he world today. I sipped it with Gorgonzola for desert and loved it. What a privilege!

This is not for me. All I get is fake cherry flavouring. It even says on the label "with real cherries and natural flavours added" Id leave the real cherries and drop the flavours. With respect this is the sort of beer that divides opinion. Think Im clear on where I sit.

Was privileged to try this brew at the downtown beer festival Las Vegas last week. Suffice to say the fact I had tried many beers at the show and was tasting from a plastic cup it is difficult to go into sensory in detail. That being said it was by far the most memorable beer of the show. Unique, very well executed and something that I can only imagine being paired with a variety of foods. Chocolate desserts and slap me down if you think Im wrong but Im thinking blue cheese. Might just have to test that theory. Was great to talk to the guys about their beers and I wish them well. If only I could get a hold of some at home in Australia.

Bottle from Purvis Cellars. Pours black and oily with an attractive shiny tan head of fine bubbles. Aroma is sweet with hints of mushroom, dark toffee, coffee and maybe even vanilla. At 9.4% Im expecting a big hit of alcohol up front and prepare for it. I am pleasantly surprised however as it is smooth and the malt and bitteress is well balanced and keeps the alcohol in place at the back of the palate where it lingers and gently  warms on the swallow. 
Ive tried making my own imperial stouts and havent been able to make an example that you could say is really enjoyable to the last drop. Always too overbearing. I suppose that is why Im not a proffessional brewer. These guys are! Deffinately getting this again.
beer_name: Red Duck Limited Release The Ox

review_blob: One of the better Australian expressions of this style. I think they pushed it a tad too far with the alcohol though. At a bout 8.5 thisd be far better balanced im my mind.
beer_name: Red Duck Limited Release 4 Ducks Strong Dark Belgian Ale

review_blob:
Bottle from Celebrations in Belmont Perth Australia. 
I was introduced to this beer over 10 years ago and its still a cracker in my mind. The thing I find most enjoyable about it is the harmony the good people at Brasserie dAchouffe have found with the rich chocolate colour, delicate spice on the nose, caramel malt flavour, velvety mouth feel and creamy finish. Each charicteristic compliments the next and there are no surprises, its just the way it should be.

We enjoyed this beer however felt it would be more suited to drinking with some food to take the edge off the citrus hoppiness. Medium bodied and creamy with a  lively head and bitter cleansing finish, Would enjoy again, ideally for entree with some salt and pepper squid or similar.
A most agreeable beer. Balanced malt sweetness with a cleansing dry finish. The smoke is definately there yet its not over powering and rich like many. Ill drink it again without doubt.
Try this beer with a hand full of smoked almonds. Not ordinarily my cup of tea however great for something different

Poured like oil out of the bottlewith a thick creamy head that disipated slowly at first before disolving totally. This beer showed incredible depth of flavour without having a heavy mouth feel that you would expect on looking at it. Bitter chocolate and coffee but something makes me think vegemite too. Enjoyed every drop.

A unique beer in apearance, bees wax colour with heavy cloud from bottle fermentation. Tried it first in 2004 and again today. From memory it was quite different the first time around but I suspect that this being very much a live ale it will be like that. Still its nice to experiance variation rather than the clinical, sterile reliability of the big brewers drops. Nice malt and hop balance, neither dominates yet both are distinct. Something different. I like it.

1994!!! Grande Reserve 750ml
This beer has been kicking around my folks place for ages, I finally conned them into opening it. I knew that it would be past its best but its still an impressive drop. No head and totally flat it poured like a glass of port (not dissimmilar in aroma too). The complexity of the nose is amazing. Herbal almost medicinal in character, raisins soaked in brandy. The hue is from watery to caramel. Flavour is malt and alcohol driven. Alcohol bitterness is balanced on the finish by malt sweetness no hop bitterness at all. A nice clean dry finish. I prefer a younger example but none the less imperssive.

Bottle Best before 08/04 So its getting on. Still holds up well. Pours pale gold to my surprise. I expected a richer amber color. Nose is of cracked grain and light caramel. Hops are faintly floral. Flavour is well balanced and slightly sweet. Hop bitterness is just enough to clean the finish. Well rounded drop.

I was thirsty at lunch time on a warm day, conditions to make almost any beer very enjoyable. Dominated by artificial passionfruit flavouring but still discernable as a witbier with zesty yeast character. I actually enjoyed it and it deserves maybe one more go.

Fine malt aroma with a matching flavour. The palate is smooth and refreshingly clean. The first litre dissapears easily and you find yourself back at the barrel for another within minutes. An experience more than a beverage. There is something about that place and you feel it as soon as you walk in the door. Dont miss it if youre in Salzburg.

Cask, Derby UK. Colden copper with cream head. Buttery Malt and floral notes on the nose. Creamy mouth feel with soft clean finish. Balanced malt sweetness and Hop bite. Went back for another pint.
Bottle, Melbourne Aus. Not nearly the same beer unfortunately.
